title: 103_s1310
content: The Act titled "Breast and Cervical Cancer Amendments of 1993" revises the program of state grants regarding breast and cervical cancer. The Breast and Cervical Cancer Amendments of 1993 revise the state grant program for breast and cervical cancer. Section 1501(b) of the Public Health Service Act is amended to allow states to expend grants for screenings through contracts with private entities. The Breast and Cervical Cancer Amendments of 1993 allow states to pay entities for screening procedures under certain conditions. Additionally, grants can be used for screenings through contracts with private entities. The Breast and Cervical Cancer Amendments of 1993 allow states to provide special consideration for projects involving high cervical or breast cancer mortality rates or incidence. Non-Federal contributions for grants may be in cash or in kind, excluding indirect or overhead costs. The Breast and Cervical Cancer Amendments of 1993 allow states to consider projects with high cervical or breast cancer rates. Non-Federal contributions for grants can be in cash or in kind, excluding Federal Government assistance. States can use donated treatment services to meet the non-Federal contribution requirement. The Breast and Cervical Cancer Amendments of 1993 allow states to consider projects with high cervical or breast cancer rates. Non-Federal contributions for grants can be in cash or in kind, excluding Federal Government assistance. States can use donated treatment services to meet the non-Federal contribution requirement. Quality assurance regarding screening procedures is amended under the Public Health Service Act. The Breast and Cervical Cancer Amendments of 1993 require that a minimum of 60 percent of the grant be spent on specific services, including screening procedures for breast and cervical cancers. Additionally, no more than 40 percent of the grant can be used for other services outlined in the act. The Breast and Cervical Cancer Amendments of 1993 mandate that at least 60 percent of the grant must be allocated to screening procedures for breast and cervical cancers. The maximum expenditure for these purposes in the first year should not exceed 50 percent of the grant. Additionally, the Secretary cannot award a grant under section 1501 without the State ensuring the quality of screening procedures. There is a transition rule in place for mammographies, maintaining the requirements of section 1503(c) of the Public Health Service Act. The Breast and Cervical Cancer Amendments of 1993 require a certificate for facilities conducting procedures under a grant. Grants can be made to tribes and tribal organizations for programs described in section 1501(a) of the Public Health Service Act. The Breast and Cervical Cancer Amendments of 1993 allow grants to tribes and tribal organizations for programs under the Public Health Service Act. Evaluations and reports for these grants are required under section 1508. Technical corrections were made to Title XV of the Public Health Service Act, including recommendations for compliance with specific sections. Establishment of a demonstration program of grants for additional preventive health services for women under Title XV of the Public Health Service Act, including supplemental grants for additional preventive health services. The Secretary may make grants to up to 3 States for demonstration projects to provide preventive health services, referrals for medical treatment, and evaluation activities under section 1501 of the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary may make grants to States for demonstration projects to provide preventive health services, referrals for medical treatment, and evaluation activities. Grants under this program must be used for screening women for breast or cervical cancer. Funding of $3,000,000 for fiscal year 1994 is authorized, with additional funding for subsequent years as needed. The authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 1995 through 1998 is contingent on funding of at least $100,000,000 under section 1510(a). A conforming amendment changes the heading of section 1510(a) to specify funding for the general program. Section 1510(a) of the Public Health Service Act is amended to allocate $200,000,000 for fiscal year 1994 and necessary sums for fiscal years 1995 through 1998.
